show.title: Elf
show.headline: The best way to spread Christmas cheer

event.title: <show-title>Elf</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: A cheerful celebration with themed games, props & singing loud for all to hear
event.description:
"Buddy the Elf, what's your favorite color?"

Don’t be a cotton-headed ninnymuggins this holiday season. Come out to Alamo Drafthouse and spread the cheer at this sugar-fueled, interactive holiday spectacular, packed with games, props, and, of course, singing loud for all to hear.

Bundle up for this celebration of one of the best holiday films ever made, period. Will Ferrell’s take on a North Pole elf trying to figure out Manhattan (“Watch out! The yellow ones don’t stop!”) just might be the funniest he’s ever been.

Our ELF Movie Party features all sorts of fun props, a gift "wrap off" before the film, and of course, your very own elf hat.

show.title: National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation
show.headline: Nothing but the best for the Griswold Family Christmas

posterImages.altText: National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation movie poster

event.title: <show-title>National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Celebrate the season like an honorary Griswold
event.description:
No one knows how to do vacations like the Griswolds. Sure, their holidays are wild, chaotic, and often fraught with peril, but everyone’s family gatherings are a little stressful, aren’t they? Fortunately, you can just let Clark and the gang shoulder all that stress while you enjoy the ride at our CHRISTMAS VACATION Movie Party.

And this party is a real beaut, with yuletide props like pine tree air fresheners, Christmas lights necklaces, and shocked cat keychains to help you feel like you're an honorary Griswold. It’ll be more fun than a membership to the Jelly of the Month Club.

show.headline: Witness the final chapter of the untold story of the witches of Oz

event.title: <show-title>Wicked: For Good</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: A wickedly fun movie party awaits
event.description: Want to take your Oz experience over the rainbow? Join us for a WICKED: FOR GOOD Movie Party, where the magic doesn’t stop at the screen. Come dressed to impress for our costume contest – there’s a fun giveaway for the most spellbinding look – and every guest will receive a bag of enchanting goodies: a Grimmerie field notebook for jotting down spells, a Green Elixir bubble bath mixer for some wicked self-care, a loofah inspired by Glinda’s iconic gown, a wind-up butterfly to release during the wedding scene, a storm cloud ribbon wand to whip up your own mini tornados, and a witch hat hair clip to top it all off. It’s the ultimate interactive celebration for good witches, bad witches, and everyone in between.

contentBlocks.paragraphs: Want to take your Oz experience over the rainbow? Join us for a WICKED: FOR GOOD Movie Party, where the magic doesn’t stop at the screen.

show.title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000): 25th Anniversary
show.headline: He puts the mean in green

landscapeHeroImage.altText: DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS

event.title: <show-title>Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000): 25th Anniversary</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Your heart will grow three sizes at our interactive movie party
event.description:
Discover the true meaning of the holiday season with this live-action adaptation of the beloved classic. Why is the Grinch such a grouch? No one seems to know, until little Cindy Lou Who takes matters into her own hands and turns both Whoville and the Grinch's world upside down, inside out…and funny side up.

Your ticket includes the following props:

  • A planner – you can't cancel dinner with yourself again!
  • Cheermeister sash – it's your responsibility to spread joy and enthusiasm this holiday season
  • Antler headband – just the thing you need to look like a reindeer
  • A snowflake – like the one on your sleeve

show.title: The Polar Express
show.headline: Journey beyond your imagination in this holiday family favorite

event.title: <show-title>The Polar Express</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: All aboard for an interactive holiday adventure the whole family will love
event.description:
Tickets, please. You can’t attend THE POLAR EXPRESS Movie Party without your ticket. And believe us when we tell you that the conductor (one of many Tom Hankses in this movie) is very particular about it.

Once you and the kiddos come aboard this special holiday movie party, we’ll have all sorts of fun surprises waiting for you, including kid-friendly props like a Santa hat, sleigh bells, and some fun activity sheets for you to take home. (And don’t worry, parents, we’ll be sure to lay down some ground rules so you’re not having to listen to jingle bells the whole time.)

With fun props, tasty treats, and more Tom Hankses than you can shake a candy cane at, THE POLAR EXPRESS Movie Party is a delightful, interactive holiday activity the whole family will love.

show.title: Black Christmas '74 + The Occupant of the Room
show.headline: A double dose of Canadian horror excellence.

event.title: <show-title>Black Christmas '74 + The Occupant of the Room</show-title>
event.headline: A double dose of Canadian horror excellence.
event.description:
About THE OCCUPANT OF THE ROOM
A schoolteacher’s late-night arrival at a hotel in the Alps without a reservation leaves him with no option but to accept the room of a missing hotel guest — leading to a sleepless night full of strange and uncanny occurrences. The narrative debut of Kier-La Janisse, director of the SXSW award-winning documentary Woodlands Dark and Days Bewitched: A History of Folk Horror, and author of the pioneering horror memoir House of Psychotic Women, is based on the classic chiller of the same name by Algernon Blackwood.

DCP courtesy of Severin Films

About BLACK CHRISTMAS
Holiday movies are sentimental and uplifting, but surprisingly devoid of knife murders. BLACK CHRISTMAS—one of the most influential Hitchcockian slashers of all time—is here to help. When sorority sisters Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder (SUPERMAN), and Andrea Martin find themselves under attack from a foul-mouthed killer, it’s up to police chief John Saxon (A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET) to even the odds. But what about Keir Dullea (2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY), the brooding art-school pianist? Could he have something to do with the mutilation rampage? BLACK CHRISTMAS is a terrifying and demented holiday tradition that gets everything right. We’d expect nothing less from Bob Clark, the pioneering director of A CHRISTMAS STORY.

4k DCP courtesy of Shout! Factory and the American Genre Film Archive

show.title: Addams Family Values
show.headline: But Debbie... pastels?

event.title: <show-title>Addams Family Values</show-title>
event.headline: This better-than-the-original sequel is kooky, spooky and really freakin' funny.
event.description:
Following the massive box office success of Barry Sonnenfeld's original THE ADDAMS FAMILY, a sequel was all but inevitable. Now with the clout that comes with financial success, the studio's reins were a little looser, and as soon as they okayed throwing a baby off a roof in the first act, Sonnenfeld & Co. knew they could pretty much do whatever they wanted in this darker and funnier sequel. And that they do! ADDAMS FAMILY VALUES sees Uncle Fester (Christopher Lloyd) get seduced by serial killer Debbie Jellinsky (Joan Cusak, in a career-best performance), while children Wednesday (Christina Ricci) and Pugsley (Jimmy Workman) get shipped off to summer camp, causing a rift in the family. It all builds up to a delightfully demented Thanksgiving-themed sequence that is still being memed to this very day. ADDAMS FAMILY VALUES joins the ranks of films like A VERY BRADY SEQUEL, aka sequels to television adaptations that dare to be more audacious, ridiculous and, as a result, much better than their predecessors. Happy Turkey Day, indeed! (Trace Thurman)

DCP courtesy of Paramount Pictures

event.description: You may not be able to actually party at Freddy Fazbear’s Pizza, but you can experience the next best thing at this interactive movie party. Before the nightmare unfolds onscreen, a live host will introduce the movie and hand out exclusive props, including a Freddy mask, Chica’s bib, a jump scare sticker, a light-up keychain, and balloons. This party has everything but the creepy animatronic animals.

show.title: Branded to Kill
show.headline: Seijun Suzuki's fractured pop art yakuza noir

event.title: <show-title>Branded to Kill</show-title>
event.headline: Seijun Suzuki’s 1967 psychosexual oddball yakuza masterpiece!
event.description:
“A killer mustn't be human. He must be tough and cool.”

In the 1960s, Japanese cinema was in the midst of a renaissance, referred to as the Japanese New Wave period. Supported financially by the studio system, directors like Yoshishige Yoshida, Masahiro Shinoda, and Seijun Suzuki were able to create widely seen films that explored the further reaches of radical politics, violence, sexuality, queerness, and marginalization. Suzuki, in particular, was incredibly prolific, directing 40 films for the Nikkatsu Company from 1956 to 1967 before the film that almost ruined him, his magnum opus, BRANDED TO KILL.

(Deep breath) This movie is bizarre, y’all. Psychosexual, bitingly satirical, and dreamily nonsensical. This picture’s a trip. BRANDED TO KILL follows the absurd and surreal journey of hitman Goro Hanada (Joe Shishido) as he flounders a mission from femme fatale Misako Nakajo (Annu Mari) and becomes the target of No. 1 Killer (Koji Nonbara), the best hitman in the business. Reveling in fractured masculinity, esoteric fetishes, and delirious forms of desire, BRANDED TO KILL is an absurdist masterpiece that queers the yakuza crime genre. Financially unsuccessful and critically panned, BRANDED TO KILL led to Suzuki being fired by the Nikkatsu Company for “making movies that make no sense and no money.” As is often the case, the misunderstood work of art went on to gather a cult following and is now appreciated for the unique, sleezy gem that it is. And we can’t wait to showcase it as part of your favorite misunderstood cult screening series, Queer Film Theory 101.

show.title: Regretting You
show.headline: Colleen Hoover's story about a devastating accident that reveals family secrets

show.title: American Psycho
show.headline: From the controversial best-seller by Bret Easton Ellis

event.title: <show-title>American Psycho</show-title>
event.headline: Now if you'll excuse me, I have to return some videotapes.
event.description:
“Look at that subtle off-white coloring. The tasteful thickness of it. Oh, my God. It even has a watermark.”

Before Christian Bale was the savior of Gotham, he was the chainsaw-wielding, business card-slinging scourge of Manhattan. Caught during the height of American Yuppieism in the late '80s, Patrick Bateman finds himself surrounded by friends who he hates and a culture he can’t stand. Can anyone blame him for allowing his nightly bloodlust to overflow into the day?

It’s hard to imagine anyone aside from Bale lecturing a soon-to-be victim on the cultural undertones found within Huey Lewis and The News’ “Hip to be Square,” all while wearing a raincoat and holding an incredibly shiny axe. But, what now seems meant to be almost wasn’t! The role was originally offered to none other than Leonardo DiCaprio. However, due to his newfound fame within the teenaged female demographic, Leo’s managers felt that a stint as a sociopathic mass murderer might somehow taint his image. I guess a career in murders and executions isn’t for everyone.

DCP courtesy of Lionsgate

show.title: Jason X
show.headline: Blast off with Jason Voorhees and his robo-machete

event.title: <show-title>Jason X</show-title>
event.headline: Blast off with Jason Voorhees and his robo-machete
event.description:
It's often considered that when a horror franchise heads to space, it's scraping the bottom of the quality barrel. From CRITTERS 4 to HELLRAISER 4 to LEPRECHAUN 4 (it's a lot of fours), each space entry has jumped the proverbial shark. But like the zombified hockey-masked killer himself, FRIDAY THE 13TH is a series that refused to be put down. Despite a dull sojourn to the Big Apple (JASON TAKES MANHATTAN) and an ambitiously terrible segue into the body-swapping genre (JASON GOES TO HELL), Jason Voorhees finally(?) goes to space in JASON X, the tenth entry in the long-running franchise. In a desperate attempt to retain audience interest in the title character while FREDDY VS. JASON was in development hell, JASON X takes a campier approach to the material, but in a very self-aware fashion. Where so many other horror space entries failed, JASON X rises to the occasion and gives new meaning to the term "headbanger." (Trace Thurman)

DCP courtesy of Warner Bros.

show.title: Maniac Cop 2
show.headline: You have the right to remain silent forever ... again!

event.title: <show-title>Maniac Cop 2</show-title>
event.headline: You have the right remain silent... forever!
event.description:
Picking up directly where MANIAC COP left off, MANIAC COP 2 is a testament to sequels that pull out all stops to be bigger, better and include far more explosions than the first film. Featuring dynamic stunt work - including death defyiing vehicle stunts on the streets of NYC - usually reserved for big budget action fare, MANIAC COP 2 is a true action/horror hybrid and may be the most ridiculous sequel of 1990 - a year which also gave us NO RETREAT, NO SURRENDER 3: BLOOD BROTHERS and TROLL 2.

4k DCP courtesy of Blue Underground.

show.title: The Shrouds
show.headline: David Cronenberg's latest film about reckoning with grief in a dystopian future

event.title: <show-title>The Shrouds</show-title>
event.headline: David Cronenberg's latest film about reckoning with grief in a dystopian future.
event.description:
In an eerie, deceptively placid near-future, a techno-entrepreneur named Karsh (Vincent Cassel) has developed a new software that will allow the bereaved to bear witness to the gradual decay of loved ones dead and buried in the earth. While Karsh is still reeling from the loss of his wife (Diane Kruger) from cancer—and falling into a peculiar sexual relationship with his wife’s sister (also Kruger)—a spate of vandalized graves utilizing his “shroud” technology begins to put his enterprise at risk, leading him to uncover a potentially vast conspiracy.

Written following the death of the director’s wife, the new film from David Cronenberg is both a profoundly personal reckoning with grief and a descent into noir-tinged dystopia, set in an ominous world of self-driving cars, data theft, and A.I. personal assistants. Offering Cronenberg’s customary balance of malevolence and wit, THE SHROUDS is a sly and thought-provoking consideration of the corporeal and the digital, the mortal and the infinite. (Janus Films

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: All Ages
sessionAttributes.description: For all ages shows, we welcome babies and kids of all ages. The no talking rules are relaxed, since kids will be kids. But other than that, you can expect the full Alamo experience.

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.
